stem: The nurse is preparing for a sterile procedure at 0900. Place the steps for donning sterile gloves in the correct order.

options.text: Pull the second glove onto the dominant hand and adjust both gloves for fit.
Open the outer glove package and place the inner wrap on a clean, dry surface.
Grasp the inner wrap's edges and open it fully, ensuring the 1-inch border is maintained.
With the dominant hand, grasp the inner cuff of the non-dominant glove and pull it onto the hand.
With the gloved non-dominant hand, slide the fingers under the outer cuff of the dominant glove.

rationale.correct: Sterile gloving technique is crucial to maintain asepsis and prevent healthcare-associated infections (HAIs). The correct sequence ensures that sterility is preserved throughout the procedure. (1) The outer glove package is considered non-sterile and protects the sterile inner wrap. (2) The 1-inch border of the inner wrap is also considered non-sterile due to potential contact with non-sterile surfaces. (3) 'Skin-to-Cuff' technique: Grasping the inner cuff of the non-dominant glove with the dominant hand ensures that only the inside of the glove (sterile) touches the skin (clean). (4) 'Glove-to-Glove' technique: Sliding the gloved non-dominant hand under the outer cuff of the dominant glove maintains sterility because sterile touches sterile. (5) Adjusting the gloves ensures a proper fit and allows for optimal dexterity during the procedure. Throughout the process, hands must be kept above the waist to avoid contamination.
rationale.incorrect: Touching the outside of the sterile glove with a bare hand compromises sterility and increases the risk of infection. Any break in sterile technique requires immediate correction.
clinicalPearls: Always maintain awareness of the sterile field. If contamination occurs, discard the contaminated items and begin again with new sterile supplies.
Proper hand hygiene before donning sterile gloves is essential to minimize the risk of introducing microorganisms into the sterile field.
Regularly assess the integrity of the sterile gloves for any tears or punctures. If compromised, replace the gloves immediately.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Always remember that the 1-inch border of the sterile field is considered non-sterile once it has been touched to open the flaps. Avoid placing sterile items on this border.

reviewUnits.heading: Surgical Asepsis and Sterile Technique
reviewUnits.body: Nurses maintain the sterile field directly in front of them and never turn their back on it. Any object below the waist is considered contaminated.

rationale.pathophysiology: Healthcare-associated infections (HAIs) are a significant concern in healthcare settings. Pathogens can be introduced into the body through breaks in sterile technique, leading to localized or systemic infections. Sterile gloving is a critical component of infection control practices, preventing the transfer of microorganisms from the healthcare provider's hands to the patient or sterile equipment. Proper technique minimizes the risk of HAIs and promotes patient safety. Failure to adhere to sterile technique can result in surgical site infections (SSIs), bloodstream infections, and other serious complications, increasing morbidity, mortality, and healthcare costs.

sbar.situation: The patient requires a sterile dressing change to a central line insertion site.
sbar.background: The patient is post-operative day 3 from a CABG and has a central line in the right subclavian vein. The insertion site dressing is soiled and requires changing using sterile technique.
sbar.assessment: The patient's vital signs are stable. The insertion site shows no signs of infection (redness, swelling, or purulent drainage) at this time, but the dressing needs to be changed to maintain asepsis.
sbar.recommendation: I recommend donning sterile gloves using proper technique to perform the sterile dressing change. Ensure all supplies are sterile and the patient is educated on the procedure to minimize contamination risk. Monitor the insertion site for signs of infection during and after the dressing change. Document the procedure and any observations.
